briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 25, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis Impacts and Warnings Domestically and Internationally
sections.content: Today, severe impacts and warnings due to climate change have been reported both domestically and internationally. Domestically, climate change is causing wildfires to occur routinely [1], and farms are suffering damage from high temperatures [3]. Internationally, spring warming trends have been observed from 1970 to 2025 [48], and concerns have been raised that increased air conditioner use due to global warming will further exacerbate climate change [44, 56]. Furthermore, climate change is threatening coffee harvests and causing price increases [50], and is also affecting drinking water in the United States [61]. Particularly, the possibility of fatal consequences for ecosystems has been raised, such as the shrinking habitat of emperor penguins and threats faced during molting [67, 71]. Globally, tropical flowers and plants are observed to be blooming weeks to months earlier or later than usual [63, 68, 74].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Domestic Carbon Neutrality and Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: Amidst this crisis, active efforts for carbon neutrality and renewable energy transition are continuing domestically. Cheonan City and Jeollanam-do are proactively responding to the climate crisis and natural disasters [2, 4, 5], while the Korea Forest Service and various organizations are developing carbon-neutral models in coastal reclaimed land [10]. Daegu Metropolitan City has achieved a cumulative renewable energy supply of 487MW, ranking first among special and metropolitan cities nationwide [18, 29, 33]. Muan-gun and Yeonggwang-gun are promoting models that link new and renewable energy profits to resident welfare and basic energy income, ushering in an 'era of energy welfare' [22, 25, 31, 36, 40]. Furthermore, large-scale energy transition projects are gaining momentum, including KOSPO's offshore wind power belt construction [14] and Boryeong City's completion of a hydrogen transportation complex base [15]. Technological innovation is also active, with LS Electric showcasing AI-based wind power generation prediction technology [32].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Climate Action and Policy Discussions
sections.content: Various attempts and discussions to address climate change are also underway in the international community. Virginia has made significant progress in responding to climate change [47], and in North Macedonia, the effectiveness of energy efficiency and renewable energy solutions for SMEs has been demonstrated through green financing facilities [70]. The U.S. renewable power grid is expected to expand to its largest scale ever this year, which is anticipated to create significant opportunities for Korea's solar and battery industries [38]. Meanwhile, the Earth Journalism Network (EJN) has begun supporting journalists in Indonesia, Thailand, and along the Bay of Bengal coast to uncover less-known impacts and report on business and climate change programs [51, 57].

sections.title: ğŸ“° Climate Change Discourse and Policy Challenges
sections.content: Policy discussions and social discourse on climate change are also ongoing. Financial authorities have announced a roadmap to mandate ESG disclosures for KOSPI-listed companies with consolidated assets of 30 trillion KRW or more starting in 2028, urging responsible corporate behavior [43]. However, despite a surge in wind power services, renewable energy grid issues persist [34]. Institutional difficulties in the energy transition process are also evident, such as Germany facing criticism for abandoning climate goals by scrapping renewable energy obligations [75]. Furthermore, disagreements on the direction of climate policy still exist, with former President Trump advocating for fossil fuel expansion under the agenda of 'drill, baby, drill' without mentioning the climate crisis [46, 76]. An analysis indicating that television climate change coverage reaches interested audiences but misses indifferent ones suggests the importance of effective information dissemination [49].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has highlighted the severity of the climate crisis, the diverse domestic and international efforts to overcome it, and the persistent policy challenges and the importance of ongoing discourse. Addressing climate change demands continuous attention, a multifaceted approach, and the active participation of all of us. This concludes the climate briefing for February 25, 2026.

articles.title: Financial Services Commission: 'KOSPI Companies with Consolidated Assets of 30 Trillion Won or More to Mandate ESG Disclosure from 2028'
articles.original_title: ê¸ˆìœµìœ„ â€œì—°ê²°ìì‚° 30ì¡° ì´ìƒ ì½”ìŠ¤í”¼ ê¸°ì—…, 2028ë…„ë¶€í„° ESG ê³µì‹œ ì˜ë¬´í™”â€
articles.description: Expansion to '10 trillion won or more' in 2029; potential conversion to statutory disclosure upon system stabilization. Greenhouse gas 'Scope 3' disclosure deferred for 3 years. Financial authorities have unveiled a roadmap mandating ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) disclosure for KOSPI-listed companies with consolidated assets of 30 trillion won or more, starting in 2028. 'Scope 3' disclosure, which calculates greenhouse gas emissions from supply chains, will be deferred for three years and applied from 2031...

summary.phenomenon: Financial authorities have announced a roadmap mandating ESG disclosure for KOSPI-listed companies with consolidated assets of 30 trillion won or more, starting in 2028. This system is scheduled to expand to companies with consolidated assets of 10 trillion won or more in 2029.
summary.outlook: 'Scope 3' disclosure, which calculates greenhouse gas emissions from supply chains, will be deferred for three years and is set to be applied from 2031. There is a possibility that the system will transition to statutory disclosure once it is firmly established.
